posts.name: Ryan Du
posts.cooked:
Hi y’all.

I was wondering what factors to be aware of while designing the electrical. For example, I know I need to give wires a little extra length, and that the pdh should be easily accessible. What else would yall recommend I keep in mind?

posts.name: T.Krauter
posts.cooked: Make sure your main breaker is securely mounted and somewhere that is easily accessible.  I’ve had to ask a number of teams during inspection to either bolt the breaker down more securely, or make it so I don’t have to reach through moving parts to turn the robot off.

posts.name: IKE
posts.cooked:
#1 … Thinking about wiring is a very good sign.  Having a plan that has some flexibility, will take you far.

Read the manual.  Minimum Wire sizes and colors for DC circuits are called out and must be followed. The minimum gauge (size) is relative to the circuit protection (snap action breaker).  The breakers help protect the wires from overheating if the load starts pulling too much current, or the wires get shorted.

Outside of the rules, you will want to figure out best practices for your team. Items to look into and decide: Connectors (or no connectors)… having good secure low resistance connectors is important.  Lots of teams have their favorites with reasons why.  There are Pros and Cons to pretty much any connector.  Without connectors, it can be hard to replace motors/sensors… Labeling.  Labeling wires at each end can be very very helpful in keeping things straight and helping root cause problems. Seperating “sensor/control” wires from power wires.  Not 100% necessary, but good idea to have them seperated due to noise potential of high power wires. CAN /signal prioritization and termination.  There are several different styles of networks or control wiring you can choose.  If going with Daisy-chain CAN , think about prioritizing your runs relative to the robt function priorities.  Most teams most years give moving high priority, and thus it should be structured to have that priority.

Wiring management.  Wires can get easily tangled or damaged in matches.  Keeping it constrained, organized, protected can help ensure you have better success and less failures.  Wire “loom” can be useful.  This is especially true if doing moving harnesses like elevators and Arms can require.

Strain Relief.  Most games have vigorous contact and having controllers anchored well with strain relief can help ensure wiring stay intact.

Have good tools.  Proper cutters, wire strippers, crimpers… they can make a big difference.

There are tons more practices, and areas to dig into, but these are some of the big ones.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
Here are 2491’s personal docs for wiring. This is what works for us not everyone, and it hasn’t been thoroughly reviewed on every part so some incorrect info might still slip in. But it’s pretty darn good.

Make sure to check all tabs!

Achieving Wiring Credentials	3 From 0 To Competition Ready Robot	4 Basic Skills, and Best Practices	5 Crimping	6 Labeling	6 Using Regular Label Maker	6 Using The Heat Shrink Label Maker	7 Wire Management	7 Routing & Bundling	7 Zip Ties	10...

posts.name: Kooper
posts.cooked:
IKE:

Strain Relief. Most games have vigorous contact and having controllers anchored well with strain relief can help ensure wiring stay intact.

emphasis on this. wire management and labeling are important but strong and safe connections are what will keep your machine driving

(I also recommend using solder seal connectors or Anderson powerpulls as opposed to wagos which can shatter with impact)

something we did on our test chassis at the start of last build season was “lay out” our runs around where our mechanisms were supposedly going to be. we made small changes as build progressed  but pretty much got the right idea. we also separated power and can runs in everything except our cable chain on our elevator, makes tracing and service a bit easier.

the main thing is making strong connections and making your electrical serviceable for when something goes wrong at comp

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
Kquig:

(I also recommend using solder seal connectors or Anderson powerpulls as opposed to wagos which can shatter with impact)

I mostly agree with this but only use solder seals as a fix, if you can plan out the correct length of wire for a run you should just use that length. Also xt60s are weirdly good for signal integrity for your canbus, just putting that out there

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: Wiring on moving parts, especially in a sleeve or energy chain, is arguably more a mechanical design problem as it is electrical. Make sure it moves how you want and not how you don’t, keep it from snagging and well contained inside your robot.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Espino
posts.cooked:
They’ve given you some excellent advice. Something that has been very helpful for us when designing the electronics for each mechanism is to start thinking about how you’re going to manage the cables from the design stage. It’s going to help a lot to make slots to mount cable ties or channels to pass the cables through. You could use bases for zip ties, but you run the risk of them coming loose. Slots make cable management easier and make it easier for everyone to know where the cables go. image 1411×744 97.3 KB screenshot from 604’s robot cad

image 1411×744 97.3 KB

image 1411×744 97.3 KB

Something I haven’t really seen is that, if you have the opportunity to, to make sure that there is pressure “forcing” wires into connectors on devices such as Radios, Limelights, VRMs, PDHs, etc. This on top of good strain relief can make it so no wire will slowly back out over a season (and you find out in playoffs that your very important wire going into your hard to reach PDH is backed itself out).
